raw_text:
Hoffman hits out over modern film
 
 Hollywood legend Dustin Hoffman has hit out at the quality of current films and theatre productions.
 
 The star of Rain Man and Tootsie said the film culture was "in the craphouse" at a press conference on Tuesday. The 67-year-old also said he stopped working a few years ago because he lost his "spark" for acting. Hoffman is in the UK to publicise his new comedy, Meet the Fockers, which also stars Robert De Niro, Barbra Streisand and Ben Stiller.
 
 He said: "You go to the cinema and you realise you're watching the third act. There is no first or second act. "There is this massive film-making where you spend this incredible amount of money and play right to the demographic. "You can tell how much money the film is going to make by how it does on the first weekend. "The whole culture is in the craphouse. It's not just true in the movies, it's also true in the theatre. "Broadway, and now London is the same, special effects are in great demand. It's not a good time culturally."
 
 Hoffman also said he stopped working a few years ago and moved into directing and writing. He said: "I just lost that spark I always had. "A couple of years ago I didn't like the parts I was getting. "Studios weren't interested in the kind of films that people of my generation wanted to see. "I thought I would stop and just try writing and directing. I wasn't aware of the depression that set in." Recently, Hoffmann has returned to film, with roles in I Heart Huckabees, Finding Neverland and now Meet the Fockers, which is the sequel to Meet the Parents. Meet The Fockers opens in the UK on Friday.
llama3.2:1b: Dustin Hoffman criticizes current film culture, stating that it prioritizes profit over artistic quality and fails to engage audiences in meaningful ways. He mentions a shift towards "demographic" filmmaking where studios focus on appealing to the largest market share rather than pushing innovative or critically acclaimed projects. Hoffman's own career took a downturn after he stopped acting due to lost enthusiasm for his craft.
llama3.2:3b: Dustin Hoffman criticizes modern film culture, calling it "in the craphouse." He believes films are focused too much on appealing to a specific demographic and making money quickly, rather than taking risks or telling meaningful stories. Hoffman also reveals he stopped acting due to losing his "spark" for the craft, but has since returned to working in the industry, including starring in Meet the Fockers.
gemma2:2b: Dustin Hoffman criticizes current film culture, claiming it lacks depth and prioritizes commercial success over artistic expression. He believes the industry has become overly focused on demographics and special effects, leading to a decline in quality. He also explains his decision to step away from acting for several years, turning to directing and writing as a result of losing his passion.  He returns to acting with roles in various films like "I Heart Huckabees", "Finding Neverland" and the sequel to "Meet the Parents," "Meet the Fockers".
qwen2.5:0.5b: Hoffman criticizes modern cinema for lackluster films and theatre productions, noting that he stopped working a few years ago due to his perceived decline as an actor. He expresses concern about the amount of money spent on films and the demand for special effects. Hoffman also mentions returning to film work after a period of idleness with roles in "I Heart Huckabees" and "Finding Neverland." The text reflects on the mismatch between the quality of modern cinema and contemporary theatre, highlighting the difficulties faced by many actors who are struggling to find success in the industry.

He stopped working a few years ago due to losing interest in acting. The discussion focuses on the decline of cinema and theater quality along with lost interest from directors and writers.

He mentioned something about the "craphouse" which he refers to as a type of film culture, saying that both in movies and theatres, this style is common due to high costs and audience preferences. He also talks about a lack of originality and a specific cultural disconnect with younger generations.

I need to make sure I include key points: his criticism of modern films lacking authenticity, mention the press conference he was at, his reasons for stopping work (spin-off roles), his statements on how money influences production and audience expectations, and his return to film after a hiatus.

Wait, does he stop working because he lost his spark or because he didn't like certain parts? I should clarify that it's about cultural disconnect rather than just acting. Also, mention the new trilogy meeting the Fockers and where it's opening in the UK.

I need to keep it concise without adding any explanations or formatting. Just the summary of key ideas and details.
</think>

Hoffman criticized modern films for lacking authenticity compared to classical cinema, stating that both genres follow a "craphouse" style due to high costs and audience preferences. He noted a lack of originality and cultural disconnect with younger audiences. Hoffman returned to film after a hiatus in I Heart Huckabees and Finding Neverland, with new trilogy meeting the Fockers opening in the UK on Friday.
